Q. Term for all possible states of a Markov decision process?
A. The state space.

text:
Q. What's the "curse of dimensionality" (with respect to RL)?
A. The size of a state space increases very rapidly (exponentially) with the number of dimensions.

selector.prefix: the state space is called this '

text:
Q. Why is it impractical to approximate the value function for a chess-playing RL agent with a lookup table? (give at least two reasons)
A. e.g. too many states to visit during training; the lookup table wouldn't fit in memory

selector.exact: When scaling these up to large state spaces there is a pair of thorny problems that we have to contend with.
selector.prefix: storing a value for every state.

text:
Q. What's wrong with using low-degree polynomials to approximate value functions?
A. They are often too low-resolution to approximate the true value function.

text:
Q. What's wrong with using high-degree polynomials to approximate value functions?
A. They often overfit to the data, meaning they don't generalise well to new, unseen data.

selector.exact: ﻿Learn strange functions that don't generalise well at high degrees

text:
Q. What's meant by overfitting in machine learning?
A. Training a model which predicts well on training data, but poorly on inputs it hasn't trained on.

selector.prefix: oint, it will. This is known as

text:
Q. What is is generalization in machine learning?
A. How well a model makes predictions about areas of input space it hasn't seen.

selector.prefix: ise to this in the y-direction.

text:
Q. What class of functions can't be represented by a polynomial?
A. Non-continuous functions (any function with discontinuities), e.g. a step function

selector.exact: They can't produce discontinuities in a policy
